General_Vegetation: General vegetation type (select up to 2 if mixed)
Weather: Describe the weather conditions during the sampling
Intermittent_or_Perennial: Is the river intermittent or perennial?
Sediment: What is the dominant sediment type of the streambed?
Distance_DS.and.MS_meters: Distance between downstream and midstream site (m)
Distance_MS.and.US_meters: Distance between upstream and midstream site (m)
US_Water.Column.Height_cm: Height of water column at upstream sampling location (cm)
US_Depositional.Type: Upstream sediment location depositional zone type
US_Algal.Mat.Coverage: At the upstream site what is the algal mat coverage?
US_Macrophyte.Coverage: At the upstream site what is the macrophyte coverage?
US_Sunlight.Access_Perc.Canopy.Cover: At the upstream site to what extent is sunlight blocked from the stream by canopy cover or other sources?
MS_Water.Column.Height_cm: Height of water column at midstream sampling location (cm)
MS_Depositional.Type: Midstream sediment location depositional zone type
MS_Algal.Mat.Coverage: At the midstream site what is the algal mat coverage?
MS_Macrophyte.Coverage: At the midstream site what is the macrophyte coverage?
MS_Sunlight.Access_Perc.Canopy.Cover: At the midstream site to what extent is sunlight blocked from the stream by canopy cover or other sources?
DS_Water.Column.Height_cm: Height of water column at downstream sampling location (cm)
DS_Depositional.Type: Downstream sediment location depositional zone type
DS_Algal.Mat.Coverage: At the downstream site what is the algal mat coverage?
DS_Macrophyte.Coverage: At the downstream site what is the macrophyte coverage?
DS_Sunlight.Access_Perc.Canopy.Cover: At the downstream site to what extent is sunlight blocked from the stream by canopy cover or other sources?
SW_pH: pH value from colorimetric pH strip
DO_perc.sat: Dissolved oxygen at 50% depth at downstream sampling location (% sat) if available
DO_mg.per.L: Dissolved oxygen at 50% depth at downstream sampling location (mg/L) if available
SW_Temp_degC: Water temperature at 50% depth at downstream sampling location(deg C)
Discharge_Link: If stream gauge/discharge data is publicly available online  provide the link. Data must be recorded at a minimum frequency of two hours.
US.or.DS.of.Gauge: Is the site upstream or downstream of gauging station?
Primary.Sources.Flow.Variation: What are the primary sources of variation in river flow?
Met.Station.Nearby: Is there a meteorological station nearby?
Met.Station: If yes name and link of meteorological station.
Precipitation.Within.Week: Was there precipitation in the last week?
Number.Days.Since.Precip: If yes number of days since precipitation.
Dam.Upstream.Site: Is there a dam upstream of the sampling location?
Dam: If yes distance from nearest dam (m) and name of dam.
Contamination.Source.Upstream: Are there any upstream contamination sources?
Contamination.Source: If yes distance type and source.
Water.Quality.Data.Available: Are there water quality data for the site?
Water.Quality.Data: If yes list types of water quality data.
Known.Data: If you have any surface water cation and/or SpC data for the site please list approximate ranges below and/or list citations in which the data can be found.
Published.Work.On.Site: Is there published work on the site?
Published.Work: If yes links and citations to published work.

Notes:
-Just below US site. the stream drops subsurface for ~8m. It appears to be due to an intact collapsed bank (that is not soggy nor does it have surface water) but could be through another subsurface channel. Upstream of sites are an old earthenwork dam that has since filled in with a meadow. 
-The DS site is small - ~0.3m2
- Summer storms are highly infrequent at this site. but there was a thunderstorm about 3-4 days before sampling.

US_Algal.Mat.Coverage: the water was very turbid. and no visual inspection was possible. I assume no algal mats present
MS_Algal.Mat.Coverage: the water was very turbid. and no visual inspection was possible. I assume no algal mats present
DS_Algal.Mat.Coverage: the water was very turbid. and no visual inspection was possible. I assume no algal mats present
Notes:
The field notes contain the following errors. which are corrected in this form:
- the written notes list the U-M distance as 5m (should be 10m). and D-M distance as 10m (should be 5m).
- access to sunlight: D and M have no shade (0% shading and 100% sunlight. instead of 100% canopy cover). The upstream site (U) has about 50% shading. 
Pictures: given the turbidity of the water. no pictures of the sediment could be taken. Sediments were collected by diving down into the water and scooping up sediment. The pictures uploaded represent the setting on land. not in the river. Sediment samples at D and M were fairly muddy. several sediment scoops at the upstream site contained a fair amount of leaves that were removed. 
Filter: the filter clogged after running the second set of replicates and at that point. we switched to the second filter (keeping the first filter clean). Filtering became difficult quickly again and filling vial ICR3 was challenging. When collecting samples for the third replicate for cations (CAT3). the sample collapsed (air might have gotten into the filter?) and water passed through the filter much more easily. We continued sampling CAT3. but the sample is much darker in color. indicating that the filter didn't work. and I suggest to discard that sample. We continued to filter the 125mL vial at the very end (S19S_0011_MER). After a little while. the filtering became harder again. so we discarded the water in it. filtered some more (~10mL). rinsed the bottle with that water and discarded it. and then filtered the required ~125mL. Thus. that sample *may* be valid. Given the above issues with filter #2. we preserved the first filter for microbial analyses with RNALater.

Associated_Site: US DOE Biological and Environmental Research (BER) Scientific Focus Area (SFA) watershed testbed site
Contamination.Source: Point and diffuse source Hg contamination beginning at the head of the creek and extending downstream.  A wastewater treatment plant discharges treated effluent approximately 8 km upstream of the sampling site.  Elevated nitrate and phosphate throughout the creek due to legacy contamination. fertilizer runoff. and effluent from the wastewater treatment plant.
Water.Quality.Data: Seven-plus years (and continuing) of 15-min data for temperature. pH. specific conductance. and dissolved oxygen.  In the early part of the record there are also 15-min data for turbidity (soon to be added again) and CDOM.
Known.Data:
Typical concentrations Ca 44 mg/L; Mg 9.8 mg/L; Na 12 mg/L; K 3 mg/L.  SpC 374 uS/cm.  See also water quality data at: https://www.esd.ornl.gov/programs/rsfa/data.shtml

Notes:
Weather was clear and sunny at the time of sampling.  The creek was very turbid due to rains the previous day.  

For the third 4-mL zero head space sample. the bottom of the glass vial cracked and fell off when screwing the lid onto the vial.  The sample was lost.

We were able to use one filter for most of the filtered water samples and had to change filters after filtering ~30 mL sample into the 125 mL PETG bottle.  It was not possible to filter an additional 700 mL through that filter.

Notes: I originally had the canopy cover percentages reversed on my datasheet. including the field photo. That is. I meant to mark 50-80% light access rather than 50-80% shade. The data entered on this online form are correct. I also had both filters clog by the time I completed the filtered water samples. and I was unable to collect the final filtered 125mL sample. Only the first filter is being returned. because there wasn't enough RNAlater to preserve the second. The river is multi-channel at the sampling site but generally is single channel. straight beyond the site.

Notes: Filter 1 (labelled as such) clogged after 2nd blue cap falcon tube.  After that: changed to Filter 2 (labelled as such).  Both filters preserved with RNAlater and sent to WHONDRS.  Filter 1 likely clogged because sediment was still disturbed after marking the locations when we began to collect samples.  Temperature and DO were measured two days prior to sampling. --- Very shallow. small stream; sampling site is at an intermittent stretch. located between perennially flowing stretches.  Usually dry during the summer. but water was running on Aug 29 follow rains the previous week. --- Pressure transducer data still being processed.  We will send it as soon as it is ready. in the next week.  --- Will also email info about nearest weather station once it is determined.

General_Vegetation: Broadleaf evergreen tree. Broadleaf deciduous tree
Known.Data:
Data for site  12 km downstream. SpC range 400-1000 depending on river conditions. The SpC is high at low flow conditions when the dam isn't releasing water. Much of the high SpC is due to high salinity effluent from a waste treatment plant that is several km downstream from the sampling site but upstream of the site 12 km from the dam where published studies have been conducted. 

https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10040-016-1365-3
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/hyp.7324
Notes: For access reasons we sampled 3 km from the USGS gauging station. I have extensive experience working in the upper 20 km of the Lower Colorado downstream from Longhorn Dam. and can confirm that the conditions at our sampling site are representative of the river conditions near the USGS gauge. There are no major inflows between the sampling site and the USGS gauge so river conditions at the gauge are also representative of conditions at the sampling site.

Known.Data: SpC range: 470-535uS/cm. Ca: 67-70mg/L. Mg: 19.5-20mg/L. Na: 4.3-5.5mg/L. K:  0.48-1.3mg/L.  Data range covers two samplings in 1996 and two samplings in past five years.
Notes: Site is over 4km north/upstream of USGS gauging station with only one tributary (Ransom Creek) in between.  Discharge correction factor of 0.89 used to remove mean tributary discharge contribution.  i.e. USGS discharge of Augusta Creek on 12 Aug 2019 = 33 ft3/s = 0.93 m3/s.  Corrected for Ransom Creek. discharge at C Avenue site = 0.83 m3/s

Notes: My assistant accidentally opened the non-acidified amber vial for 2 seconds. She did not touch the septum. We proceeded to fill the vial and send it with the other samples. We were able to fill all replicate samples and were still able to push another 720 ml of water through the filter. We could have pushed another 60-120 ml through (maybe moreWHON). I hope we captured enough microbial biomass. Our downstream site was below the USGS gage. while the mid and upstream sites were above the USGS gage.

Notes: During sampling (10:30 to 13:00. British Summer Time) a small shower happened. ---  It was not possible to flush a single additional syringe volume through the filter after all samples have been collected (step 34 of the protocol); it was already extremely difficult to fill the last bottle (125ml plastic bottle; step 33) with the same filter; I therefore. in addition. used the second filter afterwards and flushed 4 syringe volumes through it (more were not possible); however. I haven't had more RNALater and therefore could not fill the filter with RNALater afterwards. --- the longitude values on the data sheet are given in degrees WEST (and are therefore positive); the values in this form. however. are given in degrees EAST (and are therefore negative). --- the parcel was packed on Aug 20th between 11am and 12 pm

Notes: Light rain before and during sampling; stream slightly turbid. --- Deviations/possible mistakes: We were unclear on the procedure regarding the falcon tubes with RNALater for the sediments since it only mentions one of the tubes in step 3f of the protocol. We filled both of them with sample from the downstream site and went slightly above the line with one of the tubes. We also could not filter any extra syringes after filtering for all of the samples because of the amount of sediment in our stream.
